On the 17th anniversary of the capture of the bridge on 7 March 1962, a few veterans of both sides of the battle commemorated the event, attended by about 400 townspeople and students.{{cite web|last1=Hansen|first1=Ken|title=Veterans of Ludendorff Bridge battle gather at Remagen|url=http://www.stripes.com/news/veterans-of-ludendorff-bridge-battle-gather-at-remagen-1.18133#|website=Stars and Stripes|accessdate=24 November 2014|date=8 March 1962|url-status=live|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924134311/http://www.stripes.com/news/veterans-of-ludendorff-bridge-battle-gather-at-remagen-1.18133|archivedate=24 September 2015}} On the fortieth anniversary of the battle, 130 U.S. veterans visited the bridge for a memorial service. On 12 September 1991, veterans of the American and German units were added to the "Golden Book" of the community of Erpel during a commemorative ceremony. On 7 March 1995, about 600 veterans and family members from the Allied and German forces observed the 50th anniversary of the bridge's capture. During the gathering, German residents thanked the U.S. service members present for winning the war. Gerd Scheller, whose father Hans Scheller had been executed by a [[drumhead court-martial]], told attendees, "In the name of two postwar generations, I want to thank the Americans for acting as resolutely as they did on 7 March 1945."{{cite news|last1=Allen|first1=Arthur|title=Americans, Germans Celebrate Bridge Capture That Shortened War|url=http://www.apnewsarchive.com/1995/Americans-Germans-Celebrate-Bridge-Capture-That-Shortened-War/id-492b4ee8dbb80defaffec1efe374907d|accessdate=9 December 2014|date=7 March 1995|url-status=live|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141214175211/http://www.apnewsarchive.com/1995/Americans-Germans-Celebrate-Bridge-Capture-That-Shortened-War/id-492b4ee8dbb80defaffec1efe374907d|archivedate=14 December 2014}} In interviews after the war, Captain Karl Friesenhahn, who had been in charge of the demolition charges on the bridge, stated that he had successfully tested the electrical circuits controlling the charges shortly before the Americans attacked. He ruled out sabotage and stated that the circuit had definitely been cut by American artillery.{{cite web |first=Kenneth |last=Hechler |authorlink=Ken Hechler |title=Questionnaire on the Remagen Bridge Affair |work=Fold3 |accessdate=29 November 2014 |url=http://www.fold3.com/image/160228200/ |publisher=Ancestry.com |language=English, German |url-status=live |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141205081911/http://www.fold3.com/image/160228200/ |archivedate=5 December 2014 }} When the [[Ruhr Pocket]] was captured, the Allies had over 660,000 prisoners-of-war to care for, including as of 8 May 252,592 POWs in the [[Golden Mile (POW camp)|Golden Mile]] (German: Goldene Meile) camp between [[Remagen]] and [[Bad Breisig|Niederbreisig]]. The prisoners were forced to sleep on the ground. They had no sanitation and little food or water. The camp was taken over by the French on 11 July 1945, but by the time they closed it 9 days later, a total of 1,247 inmates had died of [[dysentery]], [[malnutrition]] and [[fatigue (medical)|exhaustion]].{{cite web |url=http://www.bruecke-remagen.de/ausstellung/5_de.htm |language=de |title=Ein Erdloch entlässt seine Schläfer |publisher=Friedensmuseum Brücke von Remagen |accessdate=11 December 2014 |url-status=live |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140322013322/http://www.bruecke-remagen.de/ausstellung/5_de.htm |archivedate=22 March 2014 }} The son of Maj. August Kraft, who had been executed after a show trial for his alleged responsibility in allowing the Americans to capture the bridge, sued after the war to clear his father's name. == Memorials == In the cemetery at Birnbach, Germany, a memorial was created for the four German officers executed for their "responsibility" in the capture of the bridge.{{cite web|language=German|title=Ehrenfriedhof von Birnbach|url=http://www.forum-historicum.de/militaerhistorische-sehenswuerdigkeiten-rund-um-koblenz.html|accessdate=4 December 2014|url-status=live|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129201407/http://www.forum-historicum.de/militaerhistorische-sehenswuerdigkeiten-rund-um-koblenz.html|archivedate=29 November 2014}} {{quote|(German:) Im Gedenken an Major Hans Scheller, Major Herbert Strobel, Major August Kraft, Oberleutnant Karl-Heinz Peters, gekämpft um die Brücke von Remagen, unschuldig zum Tode verurteilt in Rimbach und Oberirsen, standrechtlich erschossen am 13. und 14.3.1945. (English:) In memory of Major Hans Scheller, Major Herbert Strobel, Major August Kraft, Lieutenant Karl-Heinz Peters, fought for the Bridge at Remagen, innocently sentenced to death in Rimbach and Oberirsen, summarily shot on 13 and 14 March 1945.}} In [[Fort Jackson, South Carolina]], a stone from the pier supporting the bridge has been erected as a memorial to the [[60th Infantry Regiment (United States)|60th Infantry Regiment]], part of the 9th Infantry Division during the capture of the Ludendorff Bridge.{{cite web |url=http://www.hmdb.org/marker.asp?marker=59296 |title=Bridge at Remagen Stone |url-status=live |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141204094156/http://www.hmdb.org/marker.asp?marker=59296 |archivedate=4 December 2014 }} An M-26 Pershing Tank used by Company A's second platoon is also permanently displayed on the fort.{{cite web|title=Fort Jackson visit stirs vets' memories|url=http://www.army.mil/article/44865/|accessdate=28 November 2014|date=8 September 2010|first1=Kris|last1=Gonzalez|url-status=live|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141205040624/http://www.army.mil/article/44865/|archivedate=5 December 2014}} [[File:Remagen Trip Winter 2005 (14).JPG|thumb|right|Battle of Remagen commemorative plaques on the wall of one of the bridge towers]] Plaques commemorating the battle for the bridge have been placed by the Belgian 12th Fusilier Battalion, U.S. 9th Armored Division Association, U.S. 99th Infantry Division, and the U.S. 78th Infantry Division on the wall of the towers on the western side of the Rhine.{{cite web|title=The Bridge at Remagen|url=http://www.warhistoryonline.com/articles/the-bridge-at-remagen-a-visit.html|accessdate=30 November 2014|date=21 December 2013|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141207224743/http://www.warhistoryonline.com/articles/the-bridge-at-remagen-a-visit.html|archivedate=7 December 2014}} The 9th Infantry Division retained a foot-long piece of railroad track from the bridge as a memorial to what the division accomplished in its capture of the bridge. It is used in ceremonial activities to inspire current "Gila Battalion" engineers to "go out and perform the mission of the engineer".{{cite web|title=U.S. Army Europe combat engineers remember, honor their heritage at celebrated bridge|url=http://www.schweinfurt.army.mil/news/archives/newspage_725.htm|archive-url=https://archive.today/20141122195604/http://www.schweinfurt.army.mil/news/archives/newspage_725.htm|url-status=dead|archive-date=22 November 2014|first1=Dave|last1=Melancon|publisher=U.S. Army Europe Public Affairs Office|accessdate=22 November 2014|date=9 March 2010}} The sign that C/9th AIB placed on the north tower of the bridge is permanently displayed at the [[General George Patton Museum of Leadership|George Patton Museum]] at [[Fort Knox]], [[Kentucky]], above an [[M26 Pershing]] tank like that used to capture the bridge. === Remagen Bridge Peace Museum === In 1978, Remagen Mayor Hans Peter Kürten formulated a plan to raise money to fund a museum. When the German government decided to remove the piers because they were a navigation hazard, he persuaded the government to allow him to cast pieces of the piers into resin, which he sold. The town was able to raise more than 100.000 [[Deutsche Mark|DM]] in profits. Kürten opened the "Friedensmuseum Brücke von Remagen" (Remagen Bridge Peace Museum) on 7 March 1980 in one of the western towers.{{cite web|title=Die Brücke von Remagen|url=http://www.bruecke-remagen.de/geschichte_en.htm|accessdate=22 November 2014|url-status=live|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129085552/http://www.bruecke-remagen.de/geschichte_en.htm|archivedate=29 November 2014}}{{cite web|last1=Dougherty|first1=Kevin|title=Remagen: Museum pays homage to small German town's role in WWII|url=http://www.stripes.com/military-life/travel/remagen-museum-pays-homage-to-small-german-town-s-role-in-wwii-1.32521|accessdate=22 November 2014|date=1 March 2005|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129042520/http://www.stripes.com/military-life/travel/remagen-museum-pays-homage-to-small-german-town-s-role-in-wwii-1.32521|archivedate=29 November 2014}} Exhibits include a history of the bridge, a video documentary, information on the bridge's construction, and documentation about more than 200 wars in the region. In 2003, more than 200 German, American, and Belgian veterans of the World War II battle attended a commemorative event during the 35th anniversary of the museum. {{asof|2014}}, an American flag flies from one of the west towers and a German flag flies from the other.{{cite news|last1=Wolff|first1=Henry Jr.|title=Remagen Bridge Now a Memorial to Peace|newspaper=The Victoria Advocate|date=27 July 2003|page=3}} === Erpeler performance space === The local art and cultural company "Ad Erpelle", founded in 2006, purchased the east bridge towers and the tunnel under Erpeler Ley in 2011 for use as a performance space, preserving it for public access. The prior owner DB Netz AG had decided to permanently close the tunnels.{{cite web|title=Kunst- und Kulturkreis "Ad Erpelle" kauft ehemaligen Eisenbahntunnel|url=http://www.general-anzeiger-bonn.de/region/noerdlicher-kreis-neuwied/unkel/kunst-und-kulturkreis-ad-erpelle-kauft-ehemaligen-eisenbahntunnel-article847007.html|accessdate=7 December 2014|language=de|url-status=live|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141111130148/http://www.general-anzeiger-bonn.de/region/noerdlicher-kreis-neuwied/unkel/kunst-und-kulturkreis-ad-erpelle-kauft-ehemaligen-eisenbahntunnel-article847007.html|archivedate=11 November 2014}} === Cross on Erpeler Ley === A cross to commemorate the victims of the battle for the Ludendorff Bridge was built on the top of Erpeler Ley.{{cite book |first1=Helge |last1=Kleifield |title= Denkmale und Gedenkstätten auf der Erpeler Ley |date=January 2000 |publisher=Rhenish Association for Conservation and Landscape Protection |page= 30ff |language=de}} {{quote|(German:) Errichtet im Gedenken an die Opfer des Brückenkopfes Remagen-Erpel in den Jahren 1944/45 Gemeinde Erpel. (English:) Built in Memory of the Victims of the Remagen Bridgehead-Erpel in Year 1944/45 Erpel community}} === Peace plaque === On 20 March 2005, sixty years after the battle, a plaque commemorating the event was placed near the bridge by Heinz Schwarz, Minister of the Interior to the State of [[Rhineland-Palatinate]]. As a 16-year-old boy, he had been assigned to the top floor of a stone tower on the east shore as a telephone messenger to the bridge commander. When the bridge was captured, he escaped out the basement of the tunnel and ran home.{{cite web|title=Vor 60 Jahren überquerten die Amerikaner bei Erpel den Rhein|url=http://www.herrlichkeit-erpel.de/2005Kriegsende06.htm|accessdate=13 December 2014|language=de|url-status=live|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141213143903/http://www.herrlichkeit-erpel.de/2005Kriegsende06.htm|archivedate=13 December 2014}} {{quote|(German:) '''''Friede Ohne Freiheit Ist Kein Friede''''' —Konrad Adenauer. Gestiftet von Staatsminister A.D. Heinz Schwarz M d b 1945 Luftwaffenhelfer an der ehemaligen Ludendorffbrucke 1972–76 Innenminister des Landes Rheinland-Pfalz (English:) '''''Peace Without Freedom Is Not Peace''''' —Konrad Adenauer. Donated by Minister of State A.D. Heinz Schwarz M d b 1945 Luftwaffe auxiliary at the former Ludendorff Bridge 1972–76 Minister of the Interior of Rhineland-Palatinate}} == In popular culture == === Postcards === [[File:Remagen first day cover.jpg|thumb|Ludendorff Bridge captured 7 March 1945. Here the Watch on the Rhine fell Asleep : Americans Seized the Bridge Intact, Neutralizing Germany's ...]] On 8 September 1945, the U.S. Post Office issued a three-cent stamp commemorating the [[Liberation of Paris]] from the Germans. [[First day cover]]s were illustrated with images of the [[Ludendorff Bridge]] illustrating its capture. Other countries have issued stamps commemorating the bridge's capture, including [[Nicaragua]], [[Guyana]], [[Micronesia]], and [[Republic of the Marshall Islands]].{{cite web|title=Ponts et batailles de la seconde guerre mondiale|url=http://www.timbresponts.fr/ponts_et_hommes/conf_et_ev_dossiers/episodes_2e_guerre_mond.htm|accessdate=5 April 2015|language=French|url-status=live|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150412203213/http://www.timbresponts.fr/ponts_et_hommes/conf_et_ev_dossiers/episodes_2e_guerre_mond.htm|archivedate=12 April 2015}} === Books, film, and games === [[Ken Hechler]] was a combat historian during World War II. He was at III Corps headquarters, {{convert|16|km|sp=us}} from Remagen, when the bridge was captured. He arrived there shortly afterward and interviewed participants. He returned after the war twice to interview Germans who took part in the battle. He found Captain Willi Bratge, one of two officers who had not been executed at Hitler's orders because he had been captured, and spent a week with him in the Remagen area learning about details of the battle.
